cards.title: Business Email Compromise
cards.message: You receive an urgent email from your CEO requesting you transfer $50,000 to a vendor account for a time-sensitive project. The email address looks very similar to the CEO's official address with one letter different.

options.text: Process the transfer immediately to meet the deadline
options.feedback: BEC fraud! Never process large transfers based on email alone. Call your CEO directly on a known number to verify.

options.text: Call your CEO directly using their known phone number to verify the request
options.feedback: Excellent! BEC attacks are highly sophisticated. Always verify large requests through direct contact, not email.

options.text: Ask the vendor to confirm the account details
options.feedback: The vendor account details may be compromised too! Call your CEO directly instead to verify the entire transaction.

cards.title: Public Wi-Fi Banking
cards.message: You're at an airport with time before your flight. You notice free 'AirportFree_WiFi' network available. You decide to check your work emails and bank account while waiting.

options.text: Connect and access your banking and work email
options.feedback: Dangerous! Public Wi-Fi can be intercepted. Use mobile hotspot for sensitive tasks. Attackers create fake networks like this.

options.text: Use your phone's hotspot or wait until on a verified network
options.feedback: Perfect! Mobile hotspots are encrypted. Never access banking or work data on public Wi-Fi, even with VPN.

options.text: Use a VPN to secure the connection then proceed
options.feedback: VPN helps but public Wi-Fi networks can still be compromised. Use mobile hotspot for banking especially.

cards.title: Password Reuse
cards.message: You have 47 different passwords for various work systems. You're struggling to remember them all, so you use the same strong password for your email, banking, and work systems.

options.text: Continue using the same password across systems for simplicity
options.feedback: Critical risk! If one system is compromised, all your accounts are exposed. Use a password manager and unique passwords.

options.text: Use a password manager to create and store unique passwords for each account
options.feedback: Excellent! Password managers make this easy. Unique passwords mean one breach doesn't compromise everything.

options.text: Use two different passwords - one for work and one for personal
options.feedback: Better than one password, but still risky. Each system should have a unique password. Use a password manager.

cards.title: Personal Device Work Access
cards.message: Your company allows you to work from home using your personal laptop. IT asks if you have antivirus software and security updates installed. You haven't updated in 6 months.

options.text: Say yes to move forward quickly and install updates later
options.feedback: Risk! Your outdated device could compromise company data. Be honest with IT and update immediately before accessing work systems.

options.text: Be honest with IT, update everything, then get approval to proceed
options.feedback: Perfect! This protects both you and the company. Security updates close critical vulnerabilities.

options.text: Ask to use a company laptop instead of your personal device
options.feedback: Good idea if possible, but your personal device can be secure if properly maintained. Update now and be transparent with IT.

cards.title: Suspicious USB Device
cards.message: You find a USB drive labeled 'Executive Salary Review' in the office parking lot. Out of curiosity, you plug it into your work computer to see what's on it.

options.text: Insert it into your work computer immediately
options.feedback: Classic malware delivery! Unknown USB drives are high risk. Report it to IT security instead.

options.text: Report it to your IT department and let them investigate safely
options.feedback: Correct! This is a classic attack vector. IT has tools to safely analyze unknown devices in isolated environments.

options.text: Insert it only in an older computer with less important data
options.feedback: Still risky! Even old computers can spread malware to the network. Report to IT instead.

cards.title: Contractor Access Request
cards.message: A contractor emails your team requesting access to the company file server 'to complete their project.' They say their manager should have already authorized it. You don't recognize their manager's name.

options.text: Grant the access to keep the project moving
options.feedback: Risk! Verify through official channels first. Contact the actual project manager directly, not the email sender.

options.text: Contact your manager and IT to verify the contractor and proper access procedures
options.feedback: Perfect! Verify contractor access through official channels. Social engineering often impersonates legitimate contractors.

options.text: Grant limited access until it's verified
options.feedback: Even limited access can cause damage if unauthorized. Verify first, then grant appropriate access through proper procedures.

cards.title: Insider Information Leak
cards.message: A colleague casually mentions they've been sharing details about your company's unreleased product with friends outside the company at parties and on social media.

options.text: Say nothing - it's not your responsibility
options.feedback: This is a data breach! Report it to your manager or compliance department. Insider threats are serious.

options.text: Report it to your manager or compliance department immediately
options.feedback: Excellent! Insider threats must be reported. Your company needs to know about information leaks immediately.

options.text: Talk to the colleague privately and ask them to stop
options.feedback: While well-intentioned, this isn't enough. Formally report it so your company can protect sensitive information.

cards.title: Video Conference Zoom Bombing
cards.message: During a client video conference, a stranger joins the call and starts screaming inappropriate content, disrupting the meeting. This is a high-level client call.

options.text: Let them talk until they disconnect on their own
options.feedback: Unacceptable! Remove the disruption immediately. Lock the meeting, eject the participant, and reschedule if needed.

options.text: Remove the participant, lock the meeting, and reschedule or switch to phone
options.feedback: Perfect! Quick action protects your client relationship. Always set meeting passwords and limit participant access.

options.text: Ask them to stop and wait for them to leave
options.feedback: You need to take action immediately. Remove them and lock the meeting to prevent further disruption.

cards.title: Cloud Storage Oversharing
cards.message: Your team uses a shared cloud storage folder for client data. Someone accidentally shares it with 'anyone with the link' instead of specific team members. The link gets shared in a team chat.

options.text: Leave it as-is since it's just team chat
options.feedback: Data breach! Client data is exposed. Change permissions immediately and notify your manager.

options.text: Change permissions to 'specific people only' and notify your manager immediately
options.feedback: Correct action! Limit exposure and report the incident. Client data must be protected under data protection laws.

options.text: Delete the chat message so people forget about the link
options.feedback: Deleting won't help if someone already accessed it. Change permissions and report the incident immediately.

cards.title: Fake Invoice Scam
cards.message: You receive an invoice from what appears to be your office supplies vendor. It looks legitimate and is for $5,000. An email says to 'process this payment urgently' but doesn't match their usual format.

options.text: Process the payment immediately to avoid late fees
options.feedback: Likely fraud! Verify with the vendor directly. Compare to past invoices and confirm through official channels.

options.text: Call the vendor directly using their official phone number to verify the invoice
options.feedback: Perfect! Invoice fraud is common. Always verify large invoices through direct contact with known numbers.

options.text: Ask your manager if this invoice is legitimate
options.feedback: Good to inform them, but verify directly with the vendor yourself. Your manager may not recognize the fraud either.

cards.title: Remote Access Malware
cards.message: Your computer starts running slowly and you notice unknown processes in the task manager. You remember installing a 'helpful tool' from a download site last week to optimize your system.

options.text: Uninstall the tool and restart your computer
options.feedback: Not enough! Report to IT immediately. The tool may have installed malware that persists after uninstall.

options.text: Disconnect from the network immediately and report to IT security
options.feedback: Excellent! This prevents malware spread. IT can clean your system and check if company data was accessed.

options.text: Run your antivirus software to clean the infection
options.feedback: Antivirus might miss it. Disconnect first and let IT handle this professionally. Company data may be compromised.

cards.title: Mandatory Training Scam
cards.message: You receive an email saying 'Mandatory compliance training required' with a link to update your employee information. It claims to be from your HR department but the domain looks slightly off.

options.text: Click the link and update your information to stay compliant
options.feedback: Phishing attempt! Go directly to your company's HR portal or intranet. Notice the suspicious domain.

options.text: Go to your company's official HR portal or contact HR directly
options.feedback: Correct! Always use official channels. Phishing often impersonates compliance or security training.

options.text: Check if other colleagues received the same email
options.feedback: While checking is good, go to official sources first. Mass phishing campaigns often target many employees.

cards.title: Data Protection Compliance
cards.message: Your role involves accessing customer personal data. You realize you sometimes discuss customer details with colleagues at lunch or leave documents on your desk overnight.

options.text: Continue as-is since colleagues need the information anyway
options.feedback: Violation of data protection regulations! Only discuss what's necessary, lock documents away, and follow your company's data handling policies.

options.text: Only discuss necessary information, lock documents securely, and follow data protection policies
options.feedback: Perfect! Data protection is everyone's responsibility. These practices protect customers and your company legally.

options.text: Only avoid discussing data in front of clients
options.feedback: Data protection applies everywhere. Follow your company's information security policies in all settings.

cards.title: Mobile Device Loss
cards.message: You left your work phone at a restaurant. It contains your work email, client data, and access to your company's systems. You're 30 minutes away and can't retrieve it immediately.

options.text: Go retrieve it later after checking if you left it at home
options.feedback: Critical risk! Report it to IT immediately so they can remotely wipe it. Don't delay - someone may have already accessed it.

options.text: Call IT immediately to report it and request remote device wipe
options.feedback: Perfect! IT can remotely disable access and wipe the device. Speed is critical in device loss situations.

options.text: Change all your passwords when you get home
options.feedback: Good step but too slow! Call IT immediately for remote wipe. Assume the device is compromised.

cards.title: Suspicious Social Engineering Call
cards.message: Someone calls your office claiming to be from IT support. They say there's a critical security issue and need immediate remote access to your computer. You don't recognize their voice.

options.text: Grant remote access to fix the critical issue
options.feedback: Social engineering attack! Never grant remote access to unknown callers. Hang up and call your IT department directly.

options.text: Tell them you'll call the IT department directly and hang up
options.feedback: Perfect! Real IT support won't mind you verifying their identity. This is a common social engineering tactic.

options.text: Ask them questions to verify they're really from IT
options.feedback: Sophisticated callers can answer your questions. Don't engage. Hang up and call your company's IT directly.

cards.title: Third-Party Application Access
cards.message: A productivity app you use at work requests permission to access your Google account 'to sync documents.' You've used the app for a year. Granting access would be convenient.

options.text: Grant permission since you've trusted the app before
options.feedback: Apps can be compromised over time. Review what access it needs. If it doesn't need account access, deny it.

options.text: Review what access is requested and grant only what's necessary
options.feedback: Excellent! Even trusted apps should have minimal permissions. Only grant access to specific functions needed.

options.text: Use a separate personal account for untrusted apps
options.feedback: This app isn't necessarily untrusted, but over-permissioning is the issue. Grant only what's truly necessary.

cards.title: Team Member Performance Issue
cards.message: You notice a colleague has been working excessive overtime and seems stressed. You discover they've been secretly accessing files outside their role. When confronted, they seem evasive about why.

options.text: Ignore it - it's their personal business
options.feedback: Potential insider threat! Unauthorized file access could indicate data theft or sabotage. Report to your manager or security.

options.text: Report the unauthorized file access to your manager or security team
options.feedback: Correct! Unusual behavior + unauthorized access = potential insider threat. Your company needs to investigate.

options.text: Directly confront them about what they're accessing
options.feedback: Don't confront directly. Report to management or security. They're trained to handle these situations professionally.

cards.title: Printing Sensitive Documents
cards.message: You're about to print client financial documents in a shared office printer. You notice the printer's tray is full of uncollected documents. You can't see who they belong to.

options.text: Leave your documents in the queue and collect them later
options.feedback: Risk! Your documents could be left exposed. Collect immediately when printing and check who left the other documents.

options.text: Collect your documents immediately after printing and report the uncollected documents to IT/security
options.feedback: Perfect! Immediately collect sensitive documents and report privacy concerns. Uncollected documents are a data loss risk.

options.text: Leave the uncollected documents at the printer for the owner to find
options.feedback: Uncollected sensitive documents pose a security risk. Report them to your manager or security team.
